Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Mobile Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This funding establishes a new CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Texas State University - San Marcos focused on mobile cyber-physical systems (Mobile CPSs). The students will develop secure, efficient, and energy-aware mechanisms for various applications using the robots and sensors in the Mobile CPS Lab at the university. Students will be exposed to control and optimization theory as well as new technologies developed for Mobile CPSs. A nationwide recruitment process is used to select cohorts of undergraduate students to participate in a ten-week summer research program at the host institution. Students will be recruited from a wide range of universities, ensuring the participation of women, veterans, and minorities. The project includes mentoring by the experienced computer science faculty members, technical seminars and workshops, student presentations, and field trips and other professional development opportunities.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in strong research basis and the expertise of the faculty. The projects are in research areas that are current and address national priorities such as cyber security and sustainability. The students participate in a full range of research activities from preparing research literature reviews to production and dissemination of research results. The project has the potential to add to the emerging research base of cyber-physical systems.

The broader impacts of the project include providing a quality research experience to undergraduate students, particularly students from underrepresented groups. The project team is committed to including under-represented minority students in their research. Thus this project has the potential to produce new computer science graduate students and faculty members and to advance discovery and understanding while promoting learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF REU Site provided 44 undergraduate students with research opportunities in the area of Mobile Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS). Supervised by 5 mentors, the students developed secure, efficient and energy-aware mechanisms for several CPS applications using various mobile devices (e.g., robots, drones, sensors, and smartphones).

The students identified cyber-attacks and developed countermeasures through control and game theoretical models, designed energy-aware strategies that optimize and tradeoff energy consumption on mobile devices, and developed new assessment metrics and monitoring tools for CPS applications. This project engaged the students in an intellectual atmosphere where they discussed ideas, read and wrote research papers, presented their work in meetings and conferences, and worked with others from different backgrounds and cultures. The project provided the students with hands-on experience in configuring and implementing modules for various mobile devices. The outcomes included prototypes that were implemented in our Mobile CPS lab, 14 refereed publications, as well as a number of talks and presentations. One project was selected to be among the top 10 winning REU posters hosted in the Poster session at the Grace Hopper Conference in 2013.

Our findings contributed to and expanded the knowledge base in the emerging field of mobile CPS, especially in the areas of communication, control and security. Over the summers of 2012, 2013 and 2014, 30 students were recruited from around the nation and hosted at Texas State. More than 50% (17 participants) have published research work with their mentors. Over the academic years of 2015, 2016 and 2017, 14 local undergraduate students were engaged in research activities that resulted in 4 refereed publications. More than 30% of the participants were women, veterans and members of a minority group. Based on the REU projects, various demonstration sessions were held in our labs to promote computer science education to nearby high school students, which have between 30% to 67% of under-represented groups.
